Problem:
Consider a complex function \\(z(t) = e^{i\omega t}\\), where \\(i\\) is the imaginary unit, and \\(\omega\\) is a constant frequency. We investigate the effect of an integral transformation \\(T\\) defined by \\(T(z) = \int_0^t e^{-i\omega \tau}z(\tau)d\tau\\) over time \\(t\\).

If the integral transformation \\(T\\) is applied to \\(z(t)\\) from \\(t = 0\\) to \\(t = T\\) and allowed to evolve without further transformation, will the transformed state at \\(t = T\\) represent the simple accumulation of the original states over time?
Explanation: The transformation \\(T(z)\\) effectively changes the nature of the function by performing a convolution of \\(z(t)\\) with \\(e^{-i\omega t}\\), which does not merely accumulate but transforms the weighting of the function's contributions over time, affecting the entire structure and output at \\(t = T\\).
